data.title: The unconventional allure of Harold Wilson, pipe-puffing PM
data.meta_description: The revelation last week about the Labour prime minister’s affair with an aide gave us a glimpse into the hidden life beneath the donnish exterior
data.text:
‘Is that the one we’ve been reading about?” asked Richard Nixon, when he first met Janet Hewlett-Davies, press officer to the prime minister, Harold Wilson. In fact, the president had the wrong woman. The papers in April 1974, at the beginning of Wilson’s second stint in Downing Street, had been full of stories about another female assistant, his political secretary, Marcia Williams, engaging in property speculation; the so-called “land deals affair”. At the time, it was an amusing mistake during an intense period for Wilson. But in the light of last week’s revelations, it looks like a prescient observation.

Half a century later, we do find ourselves reading about Janet Hewlett-Davies. After her death at the age of 85 last October, Joe Haines, 96, Wilson’s
